disclaimer: This table is a non-exhaustive heuristic for flagging potential U.S. import compliance issues based on product keywords. It is not legal advice. Always confirm requirements with a qualified compliance professional or customs broker.

regulations: FDA Food Facility Registration (21 CFR 1.225)
FSVP – Foreign Supplier Verification Program
Prior Notice of Imported Food (FD&C Act 801(m))
rules.warning_message: This looks like a human food product imported into the U.S. — FDA facility registration, Prior Notice before shipment, and importer FSVP obligations are likely required.

regulations: Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act (DSHEA)
Dietary Supplement cGMPs (21 CFR Part 111)
FDA Labeling Requirements for Dietary Supplements
rules.warning_message: Dietary supplements entering the U.S. must meet FDA dietary supplement cGMPs and strict labeling rules for Supplement Facts, ingredients, and structure/function claims.

regulations: FDA Food Facility Registration
Dietary Supplement / Conventional Food Labeling (21 CFR 101)
Prior Notice of Imported Food
rules.warning_message: Powdered nutrition products can be regulated as foods or dietary supplements; ensure FDA registration, Prior Notice filing, and compliant labeling before shipping.

regulations: Infant Formula Act
21 CFR Parts 106 and 107 – Infant Formula Requirements
FDA Prior Notice and Facility Registration
rules.warning_message: Infant formula has special FDA formulation, testing, recall, and registration requirements; importing without a specialized compliance plan is extremely high risk.

regulations: CPSIA – Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act
ASTM F963 – Standard Consumer Safety Specification for Toy Safety
Children's Product Certificate (CPC) Requirements
rules.warning_message: Products marketed as toys for children under 14 generally require CPSIA compliance, ASTM F963 testing, and a Children's Product Certificate before U.S. import.

regulations: CPSIA – Lead and phthalate limits
ASTM F963 and age-graded small parts rules
Tracking label requirements for children's products
rules.warning_message: Baby and toddler products face strict CPSIA limits on lead, phthalates, and small parts, plus mandatory tracking labels and accredited third-party testing.

regulations: CPSIA – Children's Apparel
Flammable Fabrics Act – Children's Sleepwear (16 CFR 1615/1616)
Tracking label and registration requirements
rules.warning_message: Children's apparel — especially sleepwear — must comply with flammability standards, CPSIA testing, and tracking label rules before entering the U.S.

regulations: UN38.3 – Transport of Lithium Batteries
U.S. DOT / IATA Dangerous Goods Regulations
UL / IEC Safety Standards (often required by buyers)
rules.warning_message: Lithium battery products usually require UN38.3 test reports and must follow dangerous goods rules for air and ocean transport; many U.S. buyers also expect UL/IEC safety certifications.

regulations: Electrical Safety Standards (e.g., UL, ETL, IEC 62368-1)
U.S. National Electrical Code and retailer-specific requirements
rules.warning_message: Chargers and power supplies typically need recognized safety certifications (UL/ETL) to be accepted by major U.S. retailers, insurers, and marketplaces.

regulations: FCC Part 15 – Radio Frequency Devices
FCC Equipment Authorization (Certification or SDoC)
rules.warning_message: Wireless and Bluetooth products must complete FCC testing and equipment authorization before being marketed or imported into the U.S.

regulations: FCC Part 15 (unintentional radiators)
UL / ETL Safety Standards for Luminaires
Energy efficiency / labeling rules for certain lamps
rules.warning_message: LED lighting products may require FCC EMC testing and safety certifications, and certain categories face additional energy efficiency and labeling rules in the U.S.

regulations: FDA MoCRA – Modernization of Cosmetics Regulation Act
Cosmetic Facility Registration and Product Listing
Cosmetic Labeling (21 CFR 701)
rules.warning_message: Skin-care cosmetics now fall under FDA MoCRA — facilities must register, products may need listing, and labels must follow U.S. ingredient and warning requirements.

regulations: MoCRA Cosmetic Requirements
Ingredient and fragrance allergen disclosure rules
Claims review for possible OTC drug classification
rules.warning_message: Personal-care products must meet U.S. cosmetic labeling rules and, if they make drug-like claims (e.g., treating dandruff or acne), may be regulated as OTC drugs.

regulations: FDA OTC Drug Monographs
Drug Facts Label Requirements
MoCRA Cosmetic/Drug Overlap Compliance
rules.warning_message: Products like sunscreen, strong acne treatments, or antiperspirants are usually regulated as OTC drugs in the U.S. and require Drug Facts labeling and monograph compliance.

regulations: MoCRA – Cosmetic Safety Substantiation
Color Additive Regulations (21 CFR Parts 70–82)
Labeling for eye-area and lip products
rules.warning_message: Color cosmetics must use FDA-permitted color additives and maintain safety substantiation and proper labeling, especially for eye and lip use.

regulations: Flammable Fabrics Act (16 CFR 1610 – General Wearing Apparel)
Textile Fiber Products Identification Act
Country of Origin Labeling Requirements
rules.warning_message: General apparel imported into the U.S. must meet flammability standards and carry correct fiber content, manufacturer/RN, and country-of-origin labels.

regulations: Flammable Fabrics Act – Children's Sleepwear (16 CFR 1615/1616, if applicable)
CPSIA – Lead, phthalates, and tracking labels
Textile Labeling Rules for Children's Apparel
rules.warning_message: Baby and children's apparel face extra CPSIA and flammability requirements plus mandatory tracking labels; failing these can lead to recalls or seizure at U.S. customs.

regulations: Flammable Fabrics Act – Sleepwear Flammability (16 CFR 1615/1616)
CPSIA for Children's Sleepwear (if marketed for kids)
rules.warning_message: Sleepwear and pajamas are tightly regulated for flammability; children's sleepwear especially requires specific fabric performance and testing certifications.

regulations: FTC 'Made in USA' Labeling Standard
Country of Origin and Qualified U.S. Origin Claims
rules.warning_message: Using 'Made in USA' on labels or marketing requires that virtually all significant processing and materials are of U.S. origin under FTC standards; imported goods generally cannot use this claim.
